intro: Symplocos ovata, commonly known as the ovalleaf inkberry, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern Asia. It belongs to the family Ericaceae and is characterized by its small, ovate leaves that are often glossy and dark green. The plant produces small, bell-shaped white flowers in the spring, which are followed by dark blue berries in the fall. Symplocos ovata is typically found in moist, acidic soils in forests and is often used in ornamental landscaping due to its attractive foliage and berries. It plays a role in supporting local wildlife, particularly birds, which feed on its berries.
